description: Les comparaisons (plus/moins/aussi ... que) et les superlatifs (le plus/le moins)

levels.2: superlatifs: le plus, le moins + irréguliers (meilleur, pire)
levels.3: mélange avancé: comparatifs de quantité, doubles comparatifs, structures complexes

exercises.explanation: 'Plus ... que' exprime la supériorité. Marie est PLUS grande que Pierre.
exercises.translation: Marie is taller than Pierre.

exercises.explanation: 'Moins ... que' exprime l'infériorité.
exercises.translation: This movie is less interesting than the other one.

exercises.explanation: 'Aussi ... que' exprime l'égalité.
exercises.translation: Paul is as intelligent as his brother.

exercises.explanation: 'Que' introduit le deuxième élément de la comparaison.
exercises.translation: She runs faster than me.

exercises.explanation: 'Plus ... que' pour la supériorité.
exercises.translation: My cat is fatter than yours.

exercises.hint: Mot qui relie les deux éléments comparés
exercises.explanation: 'Que' est toujours nécessaire après plus/moins/aussi + adjectif.
exercises.translation: This street is as wide as the avenue.

exercises.explanation: 'Moins ... que' exprime l'infériorité.
exercises.translation: It's less cold today than yesterday.

exercises.explanation: 'Aussi ... que' pour l'égalité.
exercises.translation: My sister is as sporty as me.

exercises.hint: Mot de liaison dans la comparaison
exercises.explanation: 'Que' relie les deux éléments comparés.
exercises.translation: The train is faster than the bus.

exercises.explanation: 'Plus ... que' pour la supériorité. 'Moins' et 'aussi' sont aussi possibles selon le contexte.
exercises.translation: This exercise is more difficult than the previous one.

exercises.explanation: On utilise aussi plus/moins/aussi avec les adverbes: plus lentement que.
exercises.translation: He speaks more slowly than you.

exercises.explanation: 'Moins ... que' car Lyon est plus petit que Paris.
exercises.translation: Lyon is smaller than Paris.

exercises.explanation: 'Que' est obligatoire pour compléter la comparaison d'égalité.
exercises.translation: This pizza is as good as the restaurant's one.

exercises.explanation: 'Plus ... que' pour la supériorité.
exercises.translation: Children are noisier than adults.

exercises.hint: Mot de comparaison après moins + adjectif
exercises.explanation: 'Que' complète toujours la structure comparative.
exercises.translation: This book is cheaper than the other one.

exercises.explanation: 'Le meilleur' est le superlatif irrégulier de 'bon'. On ne dit pas 'le plus bon'.
exercises.translation: It's the best restaurant in town.

exercises.explanation: 'La meilleure' est le superlatif féminin de 'bon/bonne'.
exercises.translation: Marie is the best student in the class.

exercises.explanation: 'Le pire' est le superlatif irrégulier de 'mauvais'. 'Le plus mauvais' est aussi accepté.
exercises.translation: It's the worst movie I've ever seen.

exercises.explanation: Le superlatif se forme avec 'le/la/les plus' + adjectif.
exercises.translation: It's the highest mountain in the world.

exercises.explanation: 'Le plus long' = superlatif de supériorité.
exercises.translation: It's the longest day of the year.

exercises.explanation: 'La moins large' = superlatif d'infériorité. 'La plus étroite' marche aussi.
exercises.translation: It's the narrowest street in town.

exercises.explanation: 'Les plus' + adjectif pour le superlatif pluriel.
exercises.translation: They are the most serious students at the university.

exercises.explanation: 'Meilleur' est le comparatif irrégulier de 'bon'. On ne dit pas 'plus bon'.
exercises.translation: This cake is better than my mother's.

exercises.explanation: 'Pire' est le comparatif irrégulier de 'mauvais'. 'Plus mauvais(e)' est aussi accepté.
exercises.translation: Her grade is worse than mine.

exercises.explanation: 'Mieux' est le comparatif de 'bien'. On ne dit pas 'plus bien'.
exercises.translation: He sings better than his brother.

exercises.explanation: 'Le mieux' est le superlatif de 'bien'.
exercises.translation: He's the student who works the best.

exercises.explanation: 'La plus grande' = superlatif féminin de supériorité.
exercises.translation: Paris is the biggest city in France.

exercises.explanation: 'Les moins chères' = superlatif d'infériorité au féminin pluriel.
exercises.translation: These are the least expensive shoes in the store.

exercises.explanation: 'Meilleure' = comparatif féminin de 'bon/bonne'.
exercises.translation: This solution is better than the other one.

exercises.explanation: 'Le plus difficile' = superlatif de supériorité.
exercises.translation: It's the most difficult problem to solve.

exercises.sentence_after: de touristes cette année que l'année dernière.
exercises.explanation: 'Plus de' + nom pour comparer des quantités.
exercises.translation: There are more tourists this year than last year.

exercises.explanation: 'Moins de' + nom pour une quantité inférieure.
exercises.translation: She has less patience than him.

exercises.explanation: 'Autant de' + nom pour l'égalité de quantité. 'Aussi' s'utilise avec un adjectif, 'autant' avec un nom.
exercises.translation: I have as many books as you.

exercises.explanation: 'Autant' s'utilise après un verbe pour l'égalité. Verbe + autant + que.
exercises.translation: She works as much as her colleagues.

exercises.explanation: 'Plus ... plus ...' exprime une progression parallèle (the more ... the more).
exercises.translation: The more he eats, the more he gains weight.

exercises.explanation: 'Plus ... moins ...' = the more ... the less.
exercises.translation: The more we study, the fewer mistakes we make.

exercises.explanation: On utilise 'bien' ou 'beaucoup' pour renforcer un comparatif. Jamais 'très'.
exercises.translation: This restaurant is much better than the one next door.

exercises.explanation: 'Bien plus' ou 'beaucoup plus' pour intensifier la comparaison.
exercises.translation: He is much taller than I thought.

exercises.hint: 'De loin' renforce quel type de structure?
exercises.explanation: 'De loin' + superlatif pour insister sur la supériorité absolue.
exercises.translation: She is by far the best singer of her generation.

exercises.explanation: 'Que' devient 'qu'' devant une voyelle ou un 'h' muet.
exercises.translation: He eats more than he should.

exercises.explanation: 'Moins ... plus ...' = the less ... the more.
exercises.translation: The less we sleep, the more tired we are.

exercises.explanation: 'Plus de' + nom + 'que' pour comparer des quantités.
exercises.translation: She has more friends than her sister.

exercises.sentence_before: C'est le film le plus long
exercises.hint: Après un superlatif + nom, quel pronom relatif?
exercises.explanation: Après un superlatif, on utilise 'que' + subjonctif pour une relative.
exercises.translation: It's the longest movie I've ever seen.

exercises.hint: Égalité de quantité avec un nom
exercises.explanation: 'Autant de' + nom pour l'égalité de quantité.
exercises.translation: He has as much money as usual.

exercises.explanation: 'Un peu plus/moins' pour une petite différence.
exercises.translation: This car is a little faster than the other one.
